Executive Summary





RMP Executive Summary

GAC Chemical Corporation

Searsport, Maine   04974

December 7, 2020



1.0    GAC RISK MANAGEMENT POLICIES



GAC Chemical Corporation is committed to the safe and environmentally responsible handling, production, and storage of all chemicals and materials at its facility in Searsport, Maine.



Both of the substances regulated under the Risk Management Program at this facility, anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia are included in the facility's Process Safety Management Plan.



The safety program has been very effective in Searsport.  



2.0    PROCESSES AND SUBSTANCES SUBJECT TO 40 CFR PART 68



GAC Chemical Corporation manufactures primarily inorganic chemicals at its Searsport, Maine, facility.  With regards to 40 CFR Part 68, anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia (>20% concentration) are handled and stored at quantities exceeding the threshold quantities.



Anhydrous ammonia was first used at the site in 1956 with the startup of an anhydrous ammonia synthesis plant.  The current facility includes two horizontal storage tanks for anhydrous ammonia.  The "R-Grade Tank" (with about 18,000 gallon working capacity, or about 92,626 pounds) is located in the ammonia receiving area while the "Surge Tank" (with about 3,900 gallon working capacity, or about 41,715 pounds) is located in the ammonium sulfate production area.



Anhydrous ammonia is used at the facility to produce aqueous ammonia and ammonium sulfate.  No anhydrous ammonia is shipped from the facility.



The anhydrous ammonia is received in 86 ton capacity rail cars.  The intent is to have a maximum of five railcars stored at one time for a total storage capacity of 860,000 lbs.  The anhydrous ammonia is unloaded in a closed system using a compressor to remove vapors from the larger storage vessel and pressurizing the rail car with this vapor.  The resultant differential pressure pushes the liquefied anhydrous ammonia to the storage vessel.  The maximum pressur

e in the anhydrous ammonia system during unloading and storage is 120 psig.  The operational pressure rating for the storage vessel is 250 psig.



Transfers of liquid anhydrous ammonia from the larger storage vessel to either aqueous ammonia production or to the smaller vessel are via small transfer pumps.



The aqueous ammonia unit started production in 1995.  Aqueous ammonia is produced by injecting a controlled volume of anhydrous ammonia in a re-circulating flow of unfinished aqueous ammonia.  The batch production process is continued until the desired concentration of ammonia in the solution is reached.  The maximum batch size (limited by the working capacity of the production tank) is approximately 9,000 gallons.  Finished aqueous ammonia is stored in a tank with an approximate working capacity of 25,000 gallons.  Both of the aqueous ammonia vessels are located in a common containment structure.



Ammonium sulfate has been produced in Searsport since 1949.  A new modern production unit went into service in 1993.  The older unit was shutdown in August of that year.



Anhydrous ammonia is supplied to the ammonium sulfate process as a vapor.  The Surge Tank is coupled with a small vaporizer.  The combined units are maintained at a constant level to permit steady-state vaporization of the ammonia.  The maximum pressure in this anhydrous ammonia system during ammonium sulfate production is 120 psig.  The operational pressure ratings for both the smaller storage vessel and the vaporizer are 250 psig each.

3.0    RELEASE SCENARIOS

Four regulated processes exist at the facility. They are as follows:

Process 1: Anhydrous ammonia receiving and storage

Process 2: Aqueous ammonia production and storage 

Process 3: Ammonium sulfate production 

Process 4: Railcar storage of anhydrous ammonia

All release scenarios were analyzed using RMP*Comp for the impact radius calculations and MARPLOT for estimating the affected population within the impacted areas.  Screen shots

of these calculations are included in Attachment A.



3.1    Worst Case Scenarios

Processes 1 and 4: For both processes, the worst case is a catastrophic release from the largest vessel of anhydrous ammonia from a rail car containing 172,000 pounds of material. The calculated impact radius is 6.9 miles. The estimated population that may be affected is 9,313 in 5,217 residences. A catastrophic failure is extremely unlikely since it would require a structural failure of the stationary rail car or the impact and penetration of the vessel shell by some object of significant mass and/or velocity. The rail cars are maintained (inspections, external coatings) by their owners to prevent corrosion from the weather. The anhydrous ammonia grade shipped to GAC is not corrosive to the steel tank interior. The possibility of an object piercing the rail car vessel is very unlikely due to the isolation of the anhydrous ammonia unloading location and the absence of other activities or traffic in the area. 

Process 2: Catastrophic failure of the aqueous ammonia (29% concentration) storage tank containing 190,294 pounds of solution (55,185 pounds of 100% ammonia). The tank is located within a containment structure with a surface area of 1,424 square feet and a depth of 39 inches. The calculated impact radius is 2.7 miles. The estimated population that may be affected is 1,678 in 1,072 residences. A catastrophic failure is extremely unlikely since it would require a structural failure of the tank. The tank is maintained (inspections and coatings) to prevent external corrosion from the weather. The aqueous ammonia is not corrosive to the steel tank interior. External impact is not possible due to the physical installation of barriers. 

Process 3: Catastrophic failure of an anhydrous ammonia process tank (Surge tank) in the ammonium sulfate area containing 41,715 pounds of material. No containment or passive mitigation was used. The calculated impact radius is 3.6 miles. The estimated

population that may be affected is 2,454 in 1,456 residences. A catastrophic failure is extremely unlikely since it would require a structural failure of the stationary storage tank or the impact and penetration of the vessel shell by some object of significant mass and/or velocity. The vessel is maintained (inspections and external coatings) to prevent external corrosion from the weather. The anhydrous ammonia grade used (includes trace quantities of water) is not corrosive to the steel tank interior. The possibility of an object piercing the tank is very unlikely due to the location of the vessel and the absence of other significant activities or traffic in the area.





3.2      Alternative Case Scenarios  

Process 1 - Anhydrous Ammonia: A failure on the R-Grade tank resulting in a release of 10% of the tank volume for 10 minutes or about 926 lbs of ammonia/min. The calculated impact radius is 0.6 miles.  The estimated population that may be affected is 26 in 19 residences.  

Process 2 - Aqueous Ammonia: A failure on the 29% Aqueous Ammonia storage tank resulting in a release of 10% of the tank volume for 10 minutes or about 3,140 lbs of ammonia/min.  The calculated impact radius is 1.5 miles.  The estimated population that may be affected is 341 in 233 residences.  

Process 3 - Anhydrous Ammonia: A failure on the Surge Tank resulting in a release of 10% of the tank volume for 10 minutes or about 417 lbs of ammonia/min. The calculated impact radius is 0.4 miles.  There is no effected population. 

Process 4 - Anhydrous Ammonia: A failure on a railcar resulting in a release of 10% of the railcar volume for 10 minutes or about 1,720 lbs ammonia/min. The calculated impact radius is 0.7 miles.  The estimated population that may be affected is 26 in 19 residences.  



4.0      PREVENTION PROGRAMS

One of the required elements for a Program 3 Risk Management Plan is a Prevention Program that addresses the following elements:

?    Process Safety Information

?    Proces

s Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Management of Change

?    Pre-Startup Review

?    Compliance Audits

?    Third-Party Audits

?    Incident Investigation

?    Employee Participation

?    Hot Work Permit

?    Contractors

4.1 Process Safety Information 

The facility maintains a variety of documents that are used to help ensure safe operation of the process. These documents address (a) chemical properties and associated hazards, (b) limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and (c) equipment design information. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs) which are located in various locations onsite, on a company server, and on the internet via a cloud-based SDS service. 

The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g. automated shutdown systems).

The facility also maintains documentation that provides information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as evaluating proposed changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised. Refer to the GAC PSM Manual for more information.

4.2 Process Hazard Analysis

GAC has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



GAC primarily uses the What-If/Checklist and HAZOP analysis techniques to perform this evaluation. These are recognized

as acceptable PHA methodologies. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team identifies and evaluates potential hazards and makes recommendations to mitigate the risk.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. The final recommendations are tracked to closure, and resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the GAC facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted when major changes occur at the facility, or at minimum every five years. The results and findings from these updates are also documented and retained.  Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.3 Operating Procedures

GAC maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  These procedures are periodically reviewed to maintain correctness and annually certified as current and accurate.  In addition, procedures include key process parameters and guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedance for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available in the facility for operators and other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.  Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.4 Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, GAC has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating

a process. New employees receive basic training in facility operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. A performance review is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years, or more frequently if requested. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.  Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.5 Mechanical Integrity

GAC has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. These activities are based on ANSI/CGA 2.1 "Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" and other relevant RAGAGEP.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.



Personnel who perform maintenance activities receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.



Job plans/written procedures/checklists help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficienc

y is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. GAC incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.6 Management of Change

GAC has a comprehensive system to manage changes to covered processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment and facility information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.  Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.7 Pre-Startup Review

GAC conducts a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR involves field verification of the cons

truction and services as assurance that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.8 Compliance Audits

A compliance audit addressing all OSHA PSM and EPA RMP requirements is conducted at least every three years.  The audit team documents findings, develops recommendations, and provides the overall results to facility management in a written report. All corrective actions are tracked until they are completed, and the two most recent audit reports are retained at the facility.  Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.9 Third-Party Audits

In the event of a release of ammonia that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury, as required by RMP regulations, GAC will retain the services of a third-party to complete the next scheduled compliance audit as required by 40 CFR 68.80. Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.10 Incident investigation

GAC promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury (at least within 48 hours). The goal of each investigation is to determine the causes of the incident and develop corrective actions. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during PHAs and PHA revalidations. Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.  

4.11 Employee Participation

GA

C encourages employees to participate in all aspects of Process Safety Management (PSM) and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating operating procedures and other documents to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the facility accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan which is maintained at the facility and addresses each accident prevention program element. Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.12 Hot Work Permit

Metal cutting, grinding, oxygen-fuel gas cutting, brazing, and welding are considered "hot work".   Any time hot work is to be performed on or near a covered process, a written hot work permit system must be generated by either employees or outside contractors as required under Occupational Health & Safety Administration (OSHA) 1910.119(k). Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

4.13 Contractors

GAC uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, GAC has a program in place to evaluate contractor safety programs and performance. Facility personnel closely monitor contractor performance to ensure

that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. Refer to the GAC PSM Manual.

5.0      FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No RMP reportable releases have occurred during the past five years.

6.0      EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

The Emergency Response Plan for the facility was first published in April 1991.  The Emergency Response Plan requirements from 40 CFR 68.95 are incorporated into Integrated Contingency Plan which was last updated in 2020.  Page A8-9 of the Plan contains a list of RMP requirements cross-referenced to their location in the document.  The plan is coordinated with the Waldo County Emergency Management Agency and the Waldo County LEPC. Copies have been supplied to the Maine Emergency Management Agency, the town of Searsport and the neighboring town of Stockton Springs.
